title: 110_hr2551
content: No information provided. Congress strongly supports providing every honorably discharged veteran the opportunity to be buried in a national veterans cemetery. The Department of Veterans Affairs has set a population threshold of 170,000 eligible individuals within a 75-mile radius to establish a new national cemetery. Despite the VA's estimate of 133,000 veterans near Bellevue, Nebraska, an independent analysis found 172,500 eligible individuals. The independent analysis in Omaha, Nebraska found that 172,500 people within a 75-mile radius of Bellevue would be eligible for burial in a new national cemetery. Congress has authorized the construction of six new national cemeteries every four years since 1999. The Midwest Health Care Network of the Department of Veterans Affairs serves aging veterans in Iowa and Nebraska. Major veterans and military advocacy organizations endorse establishing a national cemetery in eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. Several veterans and military advocacy organizations in Nebraska, including Purple Heart, Air Force Sergeants Association, American Legion, and others, represent a total membership of 85,700 individuals. Establishment of a national cemetery in Sarpy County, Nebraska. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish a national cemetery in Sarpy County, Nebraska, consulting with state and local officials before selecting the site. The Secretary may accept donations of land for the cemetery. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may accept a gift of real property to establish a national cemetery. The property will be considered a gift to the United States for tax purposes. A report on the establishment of the cemetery, including costs and a schedule, will be submitted to Congress after the enactment of the Act.
